values.title: SetWorldPose timing with physics update

content.raw:
Here is the problem case:

1. Run a world in one thread.
1. In another thread, set the world pose of a model.
1. In the same thread, get the pose of a child link.

Occasionally, the returned pose of the child link will be incorrect. 

I believe is happening when the physics engine updates the pose of the link right after the other thread sets the pose of the model.

See these [pull request comments](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1049/fix-collision-getworldpose-1124/activity#comment-1893920) for an example.

To replicate the error. Modify the first test in `tests/regression/1124_collision_pose.cc`. Make the world run unpaused, remove the `world-step` function calls, and run the test about 1000 times.
content.html:
Here is the problem case:

  1. Run a world in one thread.
  2. In another thread, set the world pose of a model.
  3. In the same thread, get the pose of a child link.

Occasionally, the returned pose of the child link will be incorrect.

I believe is happening when the physics engine updates the pose of the link right after the other thread sets the pose of the model.

See these pull request comments for an example.

To replicate the error. Modify the first test in tests/regression/1124_collision_pose.cc. Make the world run unpaused, remove the world-step function calls, and run the test about 1000 times.

values.title: Light properties reset after moved by model manipulator

content.raw:
Steps to reproduce the problem:

1. Start gzserver worlds/lights.world

2. Start gzclient

3. On the world tree, select lights -> spot, the spot light is selected

4. On the toolbar, select translate mode, the manipulator is attached to the spotlight

5. Drag the light to a new location with the manipulator

6. Close gzclient, open another gzclient 

The light will be in the new position, but it became a white point light.

values.title: Automatic world population

content.raw:
Manually placing numerous models in a large environment can be tedious and
may result in unrealistic simulation worlds. Automatic population of an
environment allows a user to parametrically place models in a space.
A population of objects is defined in SDF, and parsed by Gazebo at run time.
Based on the parameters specified, a set of models will be automatically
inserted into simulation when started.

The most common type of population to create consists of inanimate objects
such as trees, rocks, and buildings. This work will exclude mobile entities,
such as robots, which often require more precise placement and are fewer in
number.

Here we specify the SDF elements that define a population.

~~~
<population>

  <!-- The set of models to place. Each child model should be unique, and 
  represents one type of model that may be place in the specified region. -->
  <models>

    <include>
      <!-- URI of the model resources -->
      <uri><uri>

      <!-- Density is multiplied by the <population_count> to determine
           the number of time to place this type of model model. -->
      <density></density>
    </include>

  </models>

  <!-- The region in which the models will be placed -->
  <region>

    <!-- Minimum bounding box region specified in world coordinates -->
    <min>X Y Z</min>

    <!-- Maximum bounding box region specified in world coordinates -->
    <max>X Y Z</max>
  </region>

  <!-- The number of models to place -->
  <model_count></model_count>

  <!-- Set to true to make sure no models overlap -->
  <prevent_collisions>true/false</prevent_collisions>

  <!-- Define how the objects will be placed in the specified region.
       The accepted values are:
       - random: Models placed at random
       - grid: Models evenly placed in a 2D grid pattern.
       - linear-x: Models evenly placed in a row along the global x-axis
       - linear-y: Models evenly placed in a row along the global y-axis
       - linear-z: Models evenly placed in a row along the global z-axis -->
  <position></position>
</population>
~~~
content.html:
Manually placing numerous models in a large environment can be tedious and may result in unrealistic simulation worlds. Automatic population of an environment allows a user to parametrically place models in a space. A population of objects is defined in SDF, and parsed by Gazebo at run time. Based on the parameters specified, a set of models will be automatically inserted into simulation when started.

The most common type of population to create consists of inanimate objects such as trees, rocks, and buildings. This work will exclude mobile entities, such as robots, which often require more precise placement and are fewer in number.

Here we specify the SDF elements that define a population.

<population>

  <!-- The set of models to place. Each child model should be unique, and 
  represents one type of model that may be place in the specified region. -->
  <models>

    <include>
      <!-- URI of the model resources -->
      <uri><uri>

      <!-- Density is multiplied by the <population_count> to determine
           the number of time to place this type of model model. -->
      <density></density>
    </include>

  </models>

  <!-- The region in which the models will be placed -->
  <region>

    <!-- Minimum bounding box region specified in world coordinates -->
    <min>X Y Z</min>

    <!-- Maximum bounding box region specified in world coordinates -->
    <max>X Y Z</max>
  </region>

  <!-- The number of models to place -->
  <model_count></model_count>

  <!-- Set to true to make sure no models overlap -->
  <prevent_collisions>true/false</prevent_collisions>

  <!-- Define how the objects will be placed in the specified region.
       The accepted values are:
       - random: Models placed at random
       - grid: Models evenly placed in a 2D grid pattern.
       - linear-x: Models evenly placed in a row along the global x-axis
       - linear-y: Models evenly placed in a row along the global y-axis
       - linear-z: Models evenly placed in a row along the global z-axis -->
  <position></position>
</population>

values.title: Deformable tire modeling

content.raw:
There are two primary modes of tire deformability / compliance:

* Normal compliance: deformation of the tire carcass, primarily in the vertical direction (see [quarter car model](http://control.ee.ethz.ch/~ifa-fp/wiki/index.php?n=Main.Modelling)
* Tangential compliance: deformation of tire at contact patch ([see figure 1 here](http://code.eng.buffalo.edu/dat/sites/tire/tire.html)), leading to relationships between friction and tire slip

For normal compliance:

* Implement something that approximates a vertical spring
* Use dart / bullet soft body. To start with, we can use a [torus model](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/blob/master/Demos/GimpactTestDemo/TorusMesh.h) used by bullet.

For tangential compliance:

* Use a simple Coulomb model
* Use a model of friction as a function of slip with linear behavior for small slip (i.e. Pacejka Magic Tire model), friction ellipse (i.e. [Dugoff](http://tiresciencetechnology.org/doi/abs/10.2346/1.3481696?journalCode=tist)), switching to Coulomb friction at low speeds

@iche033 @hsu
content.html:
There are two primary modes of tire deformability / compliance:

  • Normal compliance: deformation of the tire carcass, primarily in the vertical direction (see quarter car model
  • Tangential compliance: deformation of tire at contact patch (see figure 1 here), leading to relationships between friction and tire slip

For normal compliance:

  • Implement something that approximates a vertical spring
  • Use dart / bullet soft body. To start with, we can use a torus model used by bullet.

For tangential compliance:

  • Use a simple Coulomb model
  • Use a model of friction as a function of slip with linear behavior for small slip (i.e. Pacejka Magic Tire model), friction ellipse (i.e. Dugoff), switching to Coulomb friction at low speeds

@iche033 @hsu

values.title: GetRealTime resets with each call to gazebo::runWorld

content.html:
From #1145: the custom_main example calls gazebo::runWorld() repeatedly.

With the following modification, the example will print out sim time and real time:

diff -r b991f26d5786 examples/stand_alone/custom_main/custom_main.cc
--- a/examples/stand_alone/custom_main/custom_main.cc   Tue Jun 17 17:35:46 2014 -0700
+++ b/examples/stand_alone/custom_main/custom_main.cc   Tue Jun 24 16:45:04 2014 -0700
@@ -25,15 +25,25 @@
   // Initialize gazebo.
   gazebo::setupServer(_argc, _argv);

+  gazebo::common::Console::SetQuiet(false);
+
   // Load a world
   gazebo::physics::WorldPtr world = gazebo::loadWorld("worlds/empty.world");

   // This is your custom main loop. In this example the main loop is just a
   // for loop with 2 iterations.
-  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < 2; ++i)
+  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < 2000; ++i)
   {
     // Run simulation for 100 steps.
+    gzerr << "world " << i
+          << " sim " << world->GetSimTime()
+          << " real " << world->GetRealTime()
+          << std::endl;
     gazebo::runWorld(world, 100);
+    gzerr << "world " << i
+          << " sim " << world->GetSimTime()
+          << " real " << world->GetRealTime()
+          << std::endl;
   }

   // Close everything.

The sim time accumulates with successive calls to gazebo::runWorld(), but the real time does not accumulate.

This occurs because World::GetRealTime subtracts the value of World::startTime from the current wall time, and World::startTime is reset by each call to World::RunLoop.

For reference, gazebo::runWorld calls World::RunBlocking, which calls World::RunLoop.

values.title: Model Joints are not updated when dynamically created

content.raw:
Similar to [this issue](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1077/visualizing-dynamically-created-joints) ,  when adding new joints to a model, the [joint vector](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/f27ed5d03ca32f31a87539ae22cebcc49dd9c354/gazebo/physics/Model.hh?at=gazebo_3.0#cl-363) of the model is not updated.

It is only set once at the beginning when the model is loaded from the sdf file:

[Model::Load(sdf::ElementPtr _sdf)](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/f27ed5d03ca32f31a87539ae22cebcc49dd9c354/gazebo/physics/Model.cc?at=gazebo_3.0#cl-63)  **calls -->**  [Model::LoadJoints()](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/f27ed5d03ca32f31a87539ae22cebcc49dd9c354/gazebo/physics/Model.cc?at=gazebo_3.0#cl-120) **which calls -->**[Model::LoadJoint(sdf::ElementPtr _sdf)](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/f27ed5d03ca32f31a87539ae22cebcc49dd9c354/gazebo/physics/Model.cc?at=gazebo_3.0#cl-618) **-->** [this->joints.push_back(joint);](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/f27ed5d03ca32f31a87539ae22cebcc49dd9c354/gazebo/physics/Model.cc?at=gazebo_3.0#cl-645)

When the [CreateJoint](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/f27ed5d03ca32f31a87539ae22cebcc49dd9c354/gazebo/physics/PhysicsEngine.hh?at=gazebo_3.0#cl-140) is called from PhysicsEngine.hh to create the joint dynamically, it should also update the joints vector of the model.
content.html:
Similar to this issue , when adding new joints to a model, the joint vector of the model is not updated.

It is only set once at the beginning when the model is loaded from the sdf file:

Model::Load(sdf::ElementPtr _sdf) calls --> Model::LoadJoints() which calls -->Model::LoadJoint(sdf::ElementPtr _sdf) --> this->joints.push_back(joint);

When the CreateJoint is called from PhysicsEngine.hh to create the joint dynamically, it should also update the joints vector of the model.

values.title: Camera follow mode can't be turned off

content.raw:
Camera following was enabled in pull request #603, which included the use of the Escape key to disable camera follow mode.

I recently noticed that I can't disable camera following anymore (pressing escape doesn't turn it off). I noticed that pull request #634 introduced the use of the Escape key to switch back to the selection tool. I suspect that this keeps the follow mode from being disabled.

Based on the dates of these pull requests, I suspect that this bug affects all gazebo versions since 1.9.

Also, pressing `View -> Reset Camera` did not disable follow mode. It would be nice to use that in addition to the escape key.

values.title: Intermittent failures of RemoveModel tests in INTEGRATION_world

content.raw:
The `World::RemoveModel` function was added in pull request #1106 along with some new tests: `RemoveModelPaused` and `RemoveModelUnPaused`. I've observed intermittent failures of these tests.

One failure occurs when `World::RemoveModel` coincides with the processing of `World::dirtyPoses` in [World::Update](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0bcbb2e1b9f9b1a653b7f50e0b90b3cbd45196fd/gazebo/physics/World.cc#cl-692) ([partial backtrace](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/cb8400cf763c3f33ab2b)). There was a mutex added for dirtyposes but it was removed to preserve ABI. We should consider adding it back in.

The other failure occurs when `World::RemoveModel` coincides with the [World::BuildSceneMsg](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/0bcbb2e1b9f9b1a653b7f50e0b90b3cbd45196fd/gazebo/physics/World.cc#cl-1202) ([partial backtrace](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/d330d48146d20552a31b)). See comments [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1106/added-world-removemodel-to-fix-issue-1177/diff#comment-2137072) and [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1106/added-world-removemodel-to-fix-issue-1177/diff#comment-2137374) about this failure.
content.html:
The World::RemoveModel function was added in pull request #1106 along with some new tests: RemoveModelPaused and RemoveModelUnPaused. I've observed intermittent failures of these tests.

One failure occurs when World::RemoveModel coincides with the processing of World::dirtyPoses in World::Update (partial backtrace). There was a mutex added for dirtyposes but it was removed to preserve ABI. We should consider adding it back in.

The other failure occurs when World::RemoveModel coincides with the World::BuildSceneMsg (partial backtrace). See comments here and here about this failure.

values.title: ContactManager needs to call Clear() manually to get rid of old contacts.

content.html:
Hi there,

I noticed that the contact manager holds on to older contacts even though they are not present anymore. As a workaround I always call ContactManager::Clear() to reset all contacts.

Here is a function to test the behavior, try it with and without calling Clear(). In order to start contact publishing set the Contact View mode to On: View->Contacts

//////////////////////////////////////////////////
void MyClass::DebugOutput(std::string _msg)
{
    std::cout << _msg << std::endl;

    // get the contact manager
    physics::ContactManager* contact_manager = this->world->GetPhysicsEngine()->GetContactManager();

    std::vector<physics::Contact*> contacts = contact_manager->GetContacts();

    for (unsigned int i = 0; i < contacts.size(); i++)
    {
        physics::Collision* coll1 = contacts.at(i)->collision1;
        physics::Collision* coll2 = contacts.at(i)->collision2;

        std::cout << coll1->GetName() << " --> "<< coll2->GetName() << std::endl;
    }

    contact_manager->Clear();
}

values.title: Provide a CMake configuration file for version

content.raw:
Along with the `gazebo-config.cmake`, Gazebo should produce also a `gazebo-config-version.cmake`. 

In this way software packages that require a minimum version of Gazebo can simply write in their `CMakeLists.txt`:
```
find_package(Gazebo 3.0 REQUIRED)
```


An helper function for producing this version configuration files is provided in Cmake module `CMakePackageConfigHelpers`. Unfortunatly this module is only available on CMake version 2.8.8 or greater, while Gazebo still supports Ubuntu 12.04 that ships with CMake 2.8.7 . However is possible to write manually a `gazebo-config-version.cmake.in` file.
content.html:
Along with the gazebo-config.cmake, Gazebo should produce also a gazebo-config-version.cmake.

In this way software packages that require a minimum version of Gazebo can simply write in their CMakeLists.txt:

find_package(Gazebo 3.0 REQUIRED)

An helper function for producing this version configuration files is provided in Cmake module CMakePackageConfigHelpers. Unfortunatly this module is only available on CMake version 2.8.8 or greater, while Gazebo still supports Ubuntu 12.04 that ships with CMake 2.8.7 . However is possible to write manually a gazebo-config-version.cmake.in file.

values.title: system_gui crashes

content.raw:
Found a crash while going through the [system_gui](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials/?tut=system_plugin) tutorial.

In `GuiIface.cc`'s `gui::run()` function, the system plugin is initialized in `setupClient()` which happens before the gui is actually loaded, so the user camera is still null and causes a crash
content.html:
Found a crash while going through the system_gui tutorial.

In GuiIface.cc's gui::run() function, the system plugin is initialized in setupClient() which happens before the gui is actually loaded, so the user camera is still null and causes a crash

values.title: Physics instability when simulating large arrays of prismatic joints

content.raw:
We have noticed that the simulation becomes unstable when simulating large arrays of prismatic joints.

When the number of joints are around 280 the Gazebo simulator becomes unstable. The same effect can be seen when using ODE, Bullet, Simbody and DART.

Here is some sample code with models containing 10x10, 20x20, 30x30, 40x40, 50x50, and 100x100 arrays of prismatic joints:
https://bitbucket.org/isura/skinsim_gazebo_tests

Here is a video of a box dropped on an array of 40x40 prismatic joints with a spherical obstacle attached to each link: http://youtu.be/ySbkrZqahtQ

We have noticed that the simulation becomes unstable when simulating large arrays of prismatic joints.

When the number of joints are around 280 the Gazebo simulator becomes unstable. The same effect can be seen when using ODE, Bullet, Simbody and DART.

Here is some sample code with models containing 10x10, 20x20, 30x30, 40x40, 50x50, and 100x100 arrays of prismatic joints: https://bitbucket.org/isura/skinsim_gazebo_tests

values.title: GetForceTorque (Force Torque Sensor) in robot wrist measures incorrect forces

content.raw:
This is my first issue report, please forgive me if I have made something wrong.

I have been developing a Force Torque sensor plugin for ROS Hydro and Gazebo 1.9, and I have encountered several issues about the readings of the sensor.

The plugin reads the wrench in a specific joint and publishes it to a ROS topic. The readings are obtained with physics::JointWrench GetForceTorque(0) method. The physics engine used is the default, ODE.

These issues are:

* When an update rate of 1000 Hz is specified, when the robot is not moving, the FT sensor measures vary from +1N and -1N.
* When specifying lower update rates, after starting the simulation, the sensor readings show a force of 1N in a direction parallel to the floor. If i exert an external force in that direction, the sensor measures the exact force that i have applied, there is no 1N extra. After stopping exerting that force, the sensors indicates no force for several milliseconds, but finally that force of 1N appears again.
* The only way that I have found in order to prevent that force from appearing is moving the robot.

I am not sure what the source of this strange behavior is. If you want any more details about these issues, feel free to ask.
content.html:
This is my first issue report, please forgive me if I have made something wrong.

I have been developing a Force Torque sensor plugin for ROS Hydro and Gazebo 1.9, and I have encountered several issues about the readings of the sensor.

The plugin reads the wrench in a specific joint and publishes it to a ROS topic. The readings are obtained with physics::JointWrench GetForceTorque(0) method. The physics engine used is the default, ODE.

These issues are:

  • When an update rate of 1000 Hz is specified, when the robot is not moving, the FT sensor measures vary from +1N and -1N.
  • When specifying lower update rates, after starting the simulation, the sensor readings show a force of 1N in a direction parallel to the floor. If i exert an external force in that direction, the sensor measures the exact force that i have applied, there is no 1N extra. After stopping exerting that force, the sensors indicates no force for several milliseconds, but finally that force of 1N appears again.
  • The only way that I have found in order to prevent that force from appearing is moving the robot.

I am not sure what the source of this strange behavior is. If you want any more details about these issues, feel free to ask.

values.title: Black Screen when starting gazebo

content.raw:
When I open gazebo I sometimes (~3/4 times) get a black screen. 

I'm running the latest 2.2.2-7 debs on Ubuntu 14.04. I was having the same issue with 2.2.2-6. 

It seems to be an issue in gzserver because if I start up gzserver once and it turns out to be "good" I can restart gzclient as many times as I want and it always comes up correctly. Likewise if gzserver comes up "bad" gzclient always comes up with a black screen.
content.html:
When I open gazebo I sometimes (~3/4 times) get a black screen.

I'm running the latest 2.2.2-7 debs on Ubuntu 14.04. I was having the same issue with 2.2.2-6.

It seems to be an issue in gzserver because if I start up gzserver once and it turns out to be "good" I can restart gzclient as many times as I want and it always comes up correctly. Likewise if gzserver comes up "bad" gzclient always comes up with a black screen.

values.title: OGRE error

content.raw:
Hi,

For a while now I get this ogre error during the simulations. The problem is I cannot reproduce it all the time. I used to get them at least from version 2.0 and now I am running default branch (4.0). Here is the error:

```

gzclient: /build/buildd/ogre-1.7.4+dfsg1/OgreMain/include/OgreAxisAlignedBox.h:252: void Ogre::AxisAlignedBox::setExtents(const Ogre::Vector3&, const Ogre::Vector3&): Assertion `(min.x <= max.x && min.y <= max.y && min.z <= max.z) && "The minimum corner of the box must be less than or equal to maximum corner"' failed.
```

It usually happens when I change the visualization type, such as transparency, contact/collision visualization and afterwards I move around the scene. Or when when the objects accumulate huge forces and fly far away from the origin.

values.title: Use grouping to maintain align/snap constraints when moving models

content.raw:
When users have aligned or snapped models as desired, those relationships should be maintained when the user moves 1 or more model(s). Especially without undo, an unintended align or snap selection can bring everything out of alignment.

This can be accomplished by supporting "grouping." Users would select multiple models and press Ctrl + G to create a group.  After that, moving one model moves all grouped models accordingly. To ungroup: Ctrl + Alt* + G

* Not sure about Alt, but some second modifier key. On Macs, it's Command + Shift +G to ungroup.

values.title: Change Zoom Level of Follow Mode

content.raw:
From http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/6713/change-zoom-level-of-follow-mode

"I'm trying to closely track a robot's movement. Is there a way to adjust the zoom level of the GUI's follow function so the camera does stay on the robot and is also closer to the model?"

Also:

"Is there a way to suggest this as a future feature? I'm thinking that once follow mode is activated and the camera zooms out to 8 meters, I'm thinking the mouse's zoom function ought to be active and the zoom should hold to the new value."
content.html:
From http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/6713/change-zoom-level-of-follow-mode

"I'm trying to closely track a robot's movement. Is there a way to adjust the zoom level of the GUI's follow function so the camera does stay on the robot and is also closer to the model?"

Also:

"Is there a way to suggest this as a future feature? I'm thinking that once follow mode is activated and the camera zooms out to 8 meters, I'm thinking the mouse's zoom function ought to be active and the zoom should hold to the new value."

values.title: Collisions cannot be accessed at ConnectWorldCreated event

content.raw:
Hi,

I am running a system server plugin while re-running a saved simulation. (gazebo 4.0.0)

Since I cannot access the world in the Load() or the Init() methods, I am doing this at the **ConnectWorldCreated** event *(should I report this as a separate issue, similar to [1212](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1212/init-of-gui-system-plugin-called-before) ?)*.

This way I can access all the models and their links, but not the collisions. However, at the **ConnectWorldUpdateBegin** event the collisions appear as well.
content.html:
Hi,

I am running a system server plugin while re-running a saved simulation. (gazebo 4.0.0)

Since I cannot access the world in the Load() or the Init() methods, I am doing this at the ConnectWorldCreated event (should I report this as a separate issue, similar to 1212 ?).

This way I can access all the models and their links, but not the collisions. However, at the ConnectWorldUpdateBegin event the collisions appear as well.

values.title: Log Playback CPU 100% in pause mode

content.raw:
Hi there,

I noticed when playing back a log file, **one** CPU core stays at 100% all the time, in *pause* and *run* mode.

However, when running it with a plugin (which uses multithreading, boost::thread) the CPU load gets distributed over multiple cores and **none** of them reach 100%.

Update!!

If the plugin doesn't use multithreading (no boost::thread) the simulation runs again with one core at 100%.
content.html:
Hi there,

I noticed when playing back a log file, one CPU core stays at 100% all the time, in pause and run mode.

However, when running it with a plugin (which uses multithreading, boost::thread) the CPU load gets distributed over multiple cores and none of them reach 100%.

Update!!

If the plugin doesn't use multithreading (no boost::thread) the simulation runs again with one core at 100%.

values.title: Duplicate entity_delete request

content.raw:
While writing a world plugin that subscribes to the "~/request" topic to detect deleted objects, I noticed that there is a duplicate entity_delete callback.

Here is an annotated trace from my plugin. 

1) user adds a bowl
2) user right clicks on the bowl ...
```
#!c++
ScoringPlugin::OnRequest [entity_info, bowl]
ScoringPlugin::OnRequest [entity_info, bowl]

```
3) user selects delete (notice the duplicate message)

```
#!c++
ScoringPlugin::OnRequest [entity_delete, bowl]
ScoringPlugin::OnRequest [entity_delete, bowl]
ScoringPlugin::OnRequest [entity_delete, 23]
ScoringPlugin::OnRequest [entity_delete, bowl::link::collision__COLLISION_VISUAL__]
ScoringPlugin::OnRequest [entity_delete, bowl::link::collision]
ScoringPlugin::OnRequest [entity_delete, bowl::link]

```


branch: expose_mainwindow

values.title: ODE_INCLUDE_DIRS variable is not set

content.raw:
Our forked version of ODE does not set `ODE_INCLUDE_DIRS`, though we are using this variable in our tests ([test/integration/CMakeLists.txt](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d0428b5c36fae991fdf213200aefca4a7f4a6eae/test/integration/CMakeLists.txt?at=default#cl-2)). It is empty and does nothing.

[gazebo/physics/ode/CMakeLists.txt](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d0428b5c36fae991fdf213200aefca4a7f4a6eae/gazebo/physics/ode/CMakeLists.txt?at=default#cl-3) includes `${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/deps/opende/include` instead.
content.html:
Our forked version of ODE does not set ODE_INCLUDE_DIRS, though we are using this variable in our tests (test/integration/CMakeLists.txt). It is empty and does nothing.

gazebo/physics/ode/CMakeLists.txt includes ${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/deps/opende/include instead.

values.title: Physics interation test paramters do no work when headers are ordered incorrectly

content.raw:
while reviewing pull request #1157, it was found that certain ordering of header files can disable tests using physics engines other than the default `ode`

specifically, see this changeset d6115b9.

The `helper_physics_generator.hh` include tag has to come after `ServerFixture.hh` otherwise the test just runs with `ode`
content.html:
while reviewing pull request #1157, it was found that certain ordering of header files can disable tests using physics engines other than the default ode

specifically, see this changeset d6115b9.

The helper_physics_generator.hh include tag has to come after ServerFixture.hh otherwise the test just runs with ode

values.title: Problem compiling against gazebo using pkg-config and a local sdformat install

content.raw:
Looking at [cmake/pkgconfig/gazebo.in:10](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/40da355adddca71c1428e7176c570c48bc8407b4/cmake/pkgconfig/gazebo.in#cl-10)

it's using `-I@SDFormat_INCLUDE_DIRS@` to specify sdformat cflags. But for a local sdformat install, this generated incorrect cflag syntax in my `gazebo.pc`: 

`-I${includedir}/gazebo-4.0 -I/home/ian/local/include/sdformat-2.0;/usr/include`

the correct format should be

`-I${includedir}/gazebo-4.0 -I/home/ian/local/include/sdformat-2.0 -I/usr/include`
content.html:
Looking at cmake/pkgconfig/gazebo.in:10

it's using -I@SDFormat_INCLUDE_DIRS@ to specify sdformat cflags. But for a local sdformat install, this generated incorrect cflag syntax in my gazebo.pc:

-I${includedir}/gazebo-4.0 -I/home/ian/local/include/sdformat-2.0;/usr/include

the correct format should be

-I${includedir}/gazebo-4.0 -I/home/ian/local/include/sdformat-2.0 -I/usr/include

values.title: Bad startup on clean system

content.raw:
Gazebo produces a few error messages and takes a while to start when the `~/.gazebo` directory and ground_plane & sun models do no exist.

My solution will be to fix the error messages, and include the sun and ground_plane models inside gazebo. Both models are very small.
content.html:
Gazebo produces a few error messages and takes a while to start when the ~/.gazebo directory and ground_plane & sun models do no exist.

My solution will be to fix the error messages, and include the sun and ground_plane models inside gazebo. Both models are very small.

values.title: .gazebo/diagnostics folder has many entries

content.raw:
The [Diagnostics class](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/default/gazebo/util/Diagnostics.cc#cl-51)
creates a time-stamped folder in `~/.gazebo/diagnostics` folder even if nothing gets written to it. This leads to an extremely large number of time-stamped folders (I believe `make test` will generate them too). It make it hard to find folders that actually contain any diagnostic data.
content.html: The Diagnostics class creates a time-stamped folder in ~/.gazebo/diagnostics folder even if nothing gets written to it. This leads to an extremely large number of time-stamped folders (I believe make test will generate them too). It make it hard to find folders that actually contain any diagnostic data.

values.title: DARTPhysics::GetParam aborts for gazebo_4.0

content.raw:
I've been testing Atlas with each physics engine, and dart is aborting on startup:
~~~
[ INFO] [1408060007.884967334, 0.022000000]: waitForService: Service [/gazebo/set_physics_properties] is now available.
Error [SDF.cc:789] Missing element description for [dart]
***** Internal Program Error - assertion (dartElem != __null) failed in virtual boost::any gazebo::physics::DARTPhysics::GetParam(const string&) const:
/home/scpeters/ws/everything/src/gazebo/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTPhysics.cc(385): DART SDF element does not exist
~~~

It is caused by [DARTPhysics::GetParam, line 385](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/5d97111ac19934281d734ba134ddfa272ea3b25c/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTPhysics.cc?at=default#cl-381), which is looking for an sdf element named `dart` as a child of the world physics block. There is currently no such element in sdformat, which causes the `GZ_ASSERT` to fail.

We didn't notice this sooner because we don't have a test for PhysicsEngine::GetParam. I added such a test in 573e511 that fails for dart.
content.html:
I've been testing Atlas with each physics engine, and dart is aborting on startup:

[ INFO] [1408060007.884967334, 0.022000000]: waitForService: Service [/gazebo/set_physics_properties] is now available.
Error [SDF.cc:789] Missing element description for [dart]
***** Internal Program Error - assertion (dartElem != __null) failed in virtual boost::any gazebo::physics::DARTPhysics::GetParam(const string&) const:
/home/scpeters/ws/everything/src/gazebo/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTPhysics.cc(385): DART SDF element does not exist

It is caused by DARTPhysics::GetParam, line 385, which is looking for an sdf element named dart as a child of the world physics block. There is currently no such element in sdformat, which causes the GZ_ASSERT to fail.

We didn't notice this sooner because we don't have a test for PhysicsEngine::GetParam. I added such a test in 573e511 that fails for dart.

values.title: Scene properties are not altered on server side or SDF file

content.raw:
Steps to reproduce:

* Start gzserver and gzclient separately

* On the `World` tab click on `Scene`

* Edit `ambient` and `background` properties

Either

* Close gzclient, start a new gzclient. The Scene properties went back to default.

Or

* `File > Save World As...` : The file doesn't contain the changes in  scene properties
content.html:
Steps to reproduce:

  • Start gzserver and gzclient separately

  • On the World tab click on Scene

  • Edit ambient and background properties

Either

  • Close gzclient, start a new gzclient. The Scene properties went back to default.

Or

  • File > Save World As... : The file doesn't contain the changes in scene properties

values.title: Joint visuals are not properly oriented

content.raw:
According to [SDF 1.5](http://osrf-distributions.s3.amazonaws.com/sdformat/api/dev.html#joint372) specification, a joint `<pose>` element determines the *Pose offset from child link frame to joint frame (expressed in child link frame).*

However, for the double pendulum for example, the joint visuals are attached aligned to the parent model and depend on the initial joint values, so each time `gzclient` is started, the visuals might have a different orientation with respect to the child link:

![joints5.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4171307515-joints5.png)

Note that the `<use_parent_model_frame>` flag only applies to the `<axis> <xyz>` element and not to the pose. So as I understand it, the double pendulum joints should have their z-axis always aligned along the child link like this, independently of the initial conditions:

![joints6.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2267742801-joints6.png)
content.html:
According to SDF 1.5 specification, a joint <pose> element determines the Pose offset from child link frame to joint frame (expressed in child link frame).

However, for the double pendulum for example, the joint visuals are attached aligned to the parent model and depend on the initial joint values, so each time gzclient is started, the visuals might have a different orientation with respect to the child link:

Note that the <use_parent_model_frame> flag only applies to the <axis> <xyz> element and not to the pose. So as I understand it, the double pendulum joints should have their z-axis always aligned along the child link like this, independently of the initial conditions:

values.title: Scaling collision visuals

content.raw:
Steps to reproduce:

1. Start `gzserver` and `gzclient` separately
2. Insert a simple shape and scale it: collisions, link visuals and collision visuals get properly scaled
3. Start a new `gzclient`. Link visuals and collisions are properly scaled, but collision visuals seem to have been scaled more than once

values.title: Error when spawing a revolute joint with bullet

content.raw:
In Gazebo from default branch (but the same issue is present also in Gazebo 4.0 I guess) a bunch of error are printed when spawning a model with revolute joints with bullet. 


To reproduce, launch gazebo with bullet:
~~~
gazebo -e bullet --verbose
~~~


And try to load the "Double pendulum with base" model, you will get this errors: 
~~~
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:345] Joint must be created before getting low stop
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:333] Joint must be created before getting high stop
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:345] Joint must be created before getting low stop
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:333] Joint must be created before getting high stop
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:299] bulletHinge not yet created.
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:320] bulletHinge not yet created.
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:299] bulletHinge not yet created.
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:299] bulletHinge not yet created.
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:320] bulletHinge not yet created.
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:299] bulletHinge not yet created.
~~~


Regarding the error in lines 299 and 320 it appears that the `bulletHinge` object is not valid when the `Joint::Init()` method is called. I don't know if this issue actually causes problems later, but I am investigating some problems [1] [2] that we are experiencing with bullet hinge joints, and perhaps it is related to them. 

[1] : https://github.com/robotology/gazebo-yarp-plugins/issues/127

[2] : https://github.com/robotology/gazebo-yarp-plugins/issues/128
content.html:
In Gazebo from default branch (but the same issue is present also in Gazebo 4.0 I guess) a bunch of error are printed when spawning a model with revolute joints with bullet.

To reproduce, launch gazebo with bullet:

gazebo -e bullet --verbose

And try to load the "Double pendulum with base" model, you will get this errors: 

[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:345] Joint must be created before getting low stop
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:333] Joint must be created before getting high stop
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:345] Joint must be created before getting low stop
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:333] Joint must be created before getting high stop
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:299] bulletHinge not yet created.
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:320] bulletHinge not yet created.
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:299] bulletHinge not yet created.
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:299] bulletHinge not yet created.
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:320] bulletHinge not yet created.
[Err] [BulletHingeJoint.cc:299] bulletHinge not yet created.

Regarding the error in lines 299 and 320 it appears that the bulletHinge object is not valid when the Joint::Init() method is called. I don't know if this issue actually causes problems later, but I am investigating some problems [1] [2] that we are experiencing with bullet hinge joints, and perhaps it is related to them.

values.title: Gazebo 2.2.3 Broke Simulation Stability / Regression from 2.2.2

content.raw:
The recent 2.2.3 release has caused my simulation to go unstable with damping values which worked perfectly under 2.2.2. The fact that this happened in a patch release is really messed up.

```
[yavin:~]$ cat /var/log/dpkg.log | grep "\ upgrade\ " | grep gazebo 
2014-08-27 09:30:48 upgrade gazebo-current-dbg 2.2.2-1~precise 2.2.3-1~precise
2014-08-27 09:30:51 upgrade gazebo-current 2.2.2-1~precise 2.2.3-1~precise
```

values.title: Transport republishes old request message when spawning a new model

content.raw:
Steps to reproduce:

1.  spawn a box

2.  delete the box

3. spawn another box

Step 3 causes another `entity_delete` request msg to be published again. If you spawn a box with the same name at this step, it gets immediately deleted.

The [call to create an request publisher in Entity::Load](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/2591f9537eaeaf1ae24a48d9e86f961a9c774980/gazebo/physics/Entity.cc#cl-102
) seems to trigger the publish action.
content.html:
Steps to reproduce:

  1. spawn a box

  2. delete the box

  3. spawn another box

Step 3 causes another entity_delete request msg to be published again. If you spawn a box with the same name at this step, it gets immediately deleted.

The call to create an request publisher in Entity::Load seems to trigger the publish action.

values.title: AutoLogFixture not creating test_logs folder, prevents test log files

content.raw:
In pull request #1180, the gazebo log files were moved into an additional subfolder based on the master port. This broke the AutoLogFixture, which assumes that all logs are in `~/.gazebo/test_logs` (see [test/util.hh](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/692dc42d9d9f1073c9a9341b66ebe3af6f110d79/test/util.hh?at=default#cl-43)) and creates that directory if necessary. However, the proper folder is not being created and all AutoLogFixture tests are giving console errors. Here's an example from a [recent jenkins run](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/192/consoleFull):
~~~
1: [ RUN      ] MsgsTest.Msg
1: Error opening log file: "/var/lib/jenkins/.gazebo/test-11345/test_logs/MsgsTest_Msg.log"
1: [       OK ] MsgsTest.Msg (0 ms)
~~~

Also, the `UNIT_Console_TEST` has been [failing with timeouts](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/192/testReport/%28root%29/UNIT_Console_TEST/test_ran/), which may be related.

@caguero
content.html:
In pull request #1180, the gazebo log files were moved into an additional subfolder based on the master port. This broke the AutoLogFixture, which assumes that all logs are in ~/.gazebo/test_logs (see test/util.hh) and creates that directory if necessary. However, the proper folder is not being created and all AutoLogFixture tests are giving console errors. Here's an example from a recent jenkins run:

1: [ RUN      ] MsgsTest.Msg
1: Error opening log file: "/var/lib/jenkins/.gazebo/test-11345/test_logs/MsgsTest_Msg.log"
1: [       OK ] MsgsTest.Msg (0 ms)

Also, the UNIT_Console_TEST has been failing with timeouts, which may be related.

@caguero

values.title: option to use spacenav for user camera view point control

content.raw: since pull request #1168, if a spacenav is detected, gazebo automatically allows view point control using the spacenav.  This behavior precludes use of spacenav for other purposes (e.g. manipulate haptix links in gazebo). It would be nice to be able to disable this either via c++ api through plugin or via world sdformat xml parameters.

values.title: Improve sensor noise modeling

content.raw:
I saw a talk by @asymingt recently in which he discussed improved noise modelling in gazebo, especially for GNSS (GPS) and IMU sensors. He has already implemented much of this in [gazebo plugins in his crates repository](https://bitbucket.org/asymingt/crates/src/master/src/sim/src/plugins/model/sensors/).

Some brief history:

* Biased Gaussian noise was added to the ImuSensor in [sdformat pull request 1](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/1/fix-syntax-error-in-linksdf) and gazebo pull request #421.
* A generic `Sensor::Noise` class was created in pull request #647 and [sdformat pull request 36](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/36/gps-sensor-sensor-noise-and-spherical/diff) that supported several variants of Gaussian noise. The `Sensor::Noise` class was updated in pull request #871 and pull request #936 to allow user-defined noise functions.
* The first user of the `Sensor::Noise` class was the GpsSensor (also added in pull request #647). A `common::SphericalCoordinates` class was also introduced in this pull request for converting from a planetary spherical coordinate frame to a local Cartesian frame. It heavily uses simplifying linearizations.
* There is an outstanding issue (#831) to update the ImuSensor to use the generic sensor noise class.

@asymingt indicated in preliminary discussions that "time-correlated error and axis coupling" should be accommodated. This would probably require some additional [sdformat element definitions](http://osrf-distributions.s3.amazonaws.com/sdformat/api/dev.html#imu306). Here's a link to the [sensor noise parameters for the crates hummingbird model](https://bitbucket.org/asymingt/crates/src/ae976a3786cdf5a16cd30c663a7ac3d40b21b841/src/sim/models/hummingbird/model.sdf?at=master#cl-211).
content.html:
I saw a talk by @asymingt recently in which he discussed improved noise modelling in gazebo, especially for GNSS (GPS) and IMU sensors. He has already implemented much of this in gazebo plugins in his crates repository.

Some brief history:

  • Biased Gaussian noise was added to the ImuSensor in sdformat pull request 1 and gazebo pull request #421.
  • A generic Sensor::Noise class was created in pull request #647 and sdformat pull request 36 that supported several variants of Gaussian noise. The Sensor::Noise class was updated in pull request #871 and pull request #936 to allow user-defined noise functions.
  • The first user of the Sensor::Noise class was the GpsSensor (also added in pull request #647). A common::SphericalCoordinates class was also introduced in this pull request for converting from a planetary spherical coordinate frame to a local Cartesian frame. It heavily uses simplifying linearizations.
  • There is an outstanding issue (#831) to update the ImuSensor to use the generic sensor noise class.

@asymingt indicated in preliminary discussions that "time-correlated error and axis coupling" should be accommodated. This would probably require some additional sdformat element definitions. Here's a link to the sensor noise parameters for the crates hummingbird model.

values.title: Change frame of a link/joint without moving the link joint

content.raw:
Make it possible to change the frame of a link/joint without the link joint. This would allow to simulate mecanum wheels ([see here how](http://www.forum.coppeliarobotics.com/viewtopic.php?f=9&t=390#p1380)).

This functionality is close to [simResetDynamicObject](http://www.coppeliarobotics.com/helpFiles/en/apiFunctions.htm#simResetDynamicObject) in v-rep.

This issue is linked to this [question in gazebo answers](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/7126/change-frame-of-a-linkjoint-without-moving-the/).
content.html:
Make it possible to change the frame of a link/joint without the link joint. This would allow to simulate mecanum wheels (see here how).

This functionality is close to simResetDynamicObject in v-rep.

This issue is linked to this question in gazebo answers.

values.title: Missing Gazebo/Chrome material

content.raw: The `ball_bearing` model wants to use [Gazebo/Chrome](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/3517d8ee5bddf9ba8b251eec6b223fcdfd6c4c6b/ball_bearing/model.rsdf#cl-50) as a material, but it doesn't exist in [gazebo.material](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/default/media/materials/scripts/gazebo.material). I didn't see any shiny metal materials in that file, which would be nice to have.
content.html: The ball_bearing model wants to use Gazebo/Chrome as a material, but it doesn't exist in gazebo.material. I didn't see any shiny metal materials in that file, which would be nice to have.

values.title: Display non-pure joint axes

content.raw: In the current version of gazebo, the joint axes are visualized via a small circle mark in 3D at the top of the joint frame axes. Now this only allows to display joint axes which are aligned with one of the canonical axes of the joint frame. If the joint axis is not a frame's canonical axis, there is no display. This should be changed as joint axes can normally take any value.
content.html: In the current version of gazebo, the joint axes are visualized via a small circle mark in 3D at the top of the joint frame axes. Now this only allows to display joint axes which are aligned with one of the canonical axes of the joint frame. If the joint axis is not a frame's canonical axis, there is no display. This should be changed as joint axes can normally take any value.

values.title: Compilation error with protobuf 2.6.0

content.raw:
It was initially reported on the [osrf/simulation homebrew tap](https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/issues/29), and I have confirmed on my mac that protobuf 2.6.0 causes compilation errors in gazebo.

One issue is a symbol collision for `TYPE_BOOL`. There may be multiple variants of this issue, here's [one from 2009](http://code.google.com/p/protobuf/issues/detail?id=119). Also, we have an `#undef TYPE_BOOL` in [ModelListWidget.cc](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/4b0732be863890410ca5dbf27c3373c79939fa83/gazebo/gui/ModelListWidget.cc?at=default#cl-55), which looks similar, though I don't know what changed in protobuf 2.6.0 to break this.
content.html:
It was initially reported on the osrf/simulation homebrew tap, and I have confirmed on my mac that protobuf 2.6.0 causes compilation errors in gazebo.

One issue is a symbol collision for TYPE_BOOL. There may be multiple variants of this issue, here's one from 2009. Also, we have an #undef TYPE_BOOL in ModelListWidget.cc, which looks similar, though I don't know what changed in protobuf 2.6.0 to break this.

values.title: GPU laser and ogre test failures with ATI

content.raw:
There are several test failures when using an ATI GPU
([reference build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-ati/561)):

* [GPURaySensor_TEST/CreateLaser](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-ati/561/testReport/%28root%29/GPURaySensor_TEST/CreateLaser/)
* [GPURaySensor_TEST/LaserUnitBox](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-ati/561/testReport/%28root%29/GPURaySensorTest/LaserUnitBox/)
* [GPURaySensorTest/Heightmap](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-ati/561/testReport/%28root%29/GPURaySensorTest/Heightmap/)
* [OgreLog/PubSub](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-ati/561/testReport/%28root%29/OgreLog/PubSub/)

The OgreLog test may be the most useful in identifying problems.
content.html:
There are several test failures when using an ATI GPU (reference build):

  • GPURaySensor_TEST/CreateLaser
  • GPURaySensor_TEST/LaserUnitBox
  • GPURaySensorTest/Heightmap
  • OgreLog/PubSub

The OgreLog test may be the most useful in identifying problems.

values.title: Inclusion of magnetic field strength sensor

content.raw:
What would be really useful to multirotor research is the inclusion of a magnetic field strength sensor to compliment the IMU sensor already in Gazebo. What I propose is the following...

In the world SDF file...

```
#!xml

<physics>
   <magnetic>0.10 0.7 0.1</magnetic>
</physics>
```

And, in the model SDF file...

```
#!xml

<sensor name="HMC5843" type="magnetometer">
  <pose>0.01 0 0.03 0 -0 0</pose>
  <magnetometer>
    <noise>
      <type>gaussian</type>
      <mean>0.0</mean>
      <stddev>0.01</stddev>
    </noise>
  </magnetometer>
</sensor>

```

The sensor itself would just take the global magnetic field strength vector, and rotate it from the world frame into the current sensor pose.

Thoughts?

values.title: Hector Rolling Landscape Broken Mesh

content.raw:
The rolling landscape world from [hector_gazebo_worlds](http://wiki.ros.org/hector_gazebo_worlds) now appears as an invalid mesh in recent distributed Gazebo packages (similar results in both Gazebo 1.9.6 and 4.0.2). The same world file rendered correctly recently as a few months ago.

![Gazebo 1.9.6 with hector rolling landscape world](ftp://ftp.ll.mit.edu/outgoing/boulet/gazebo_hector_rolling_landscape.png)

Running the Collada file through meshlab corrects the rendering issues, but the landscape no longer appears smooth.
content.html:
The rolling landscape world from hector_gazebo_worlds now appears as an invalid mesh in recent distributed Gazebo packages (similar results in both Gazebo 1.9.6 and 4.0.2). The same world file rendered correctly recently as a few months ago.

Running the Collada file through meshlab corrects the rendering issues, but the landscape no longer appears smooth.

values.title: Rename 'gps' sensor to 'gnss'

content.raw:
This may be a bit of a controversial, and perhaps a bit of a pedantic, point. The Global Positioning System (GPS) is one of several different Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS). Many of the newer GNSS chipsets include support for not only GPS (USA), but also the GLONASS (Russian) and Galileo (EU) systems. I expect that the QZSS (Japan) and Compass (China) systems will also become more widely-supported in the not too distant future. Some examples of newer chipsets...

- http://www.nvs-gnss.com/products/receivers/item/2-nv08c-csm.html
- http://www.u-blox.com/en/gps-modules/u-blox-6-timing-module/lea-m8f-precision-timing-gnss-module.html

Electing the nomenclature 'gps' for a GNSS sensor in Gazebo suggests that the sensor is restricted to one satellite system, whereas it may not be.

I'm not too sure how difficult the change would be, and if it is worth all of the hassle it may create. However, it may be good to keep this in mind if an opportunity arises where it can be renamed without too much overhead.

The reason I am being pedantic about this is that I have written a single-frequency multi-constellation GNSS error model, which I'd like to repackage as a sensor plugin. I'm in the process of testing the model on real data, and I will distribute it as a separate project from CRATES when it's in good shape / the paper is written :)
content.html:

Many of the newer GNSS chipsets include support for not only GPS (USA), but also the GLONASS (Russian) and Galileo (EU) systems. I expect that the QZSS (Japan) and Compass (China) systems will also become more widely-supported in the not too distant future. Some examples of newer chipsets...

  • http://www.nvs-gnss.com/products/receivers/item/2-nv08c-csm.html
  • http://www.u-blox.com/en/gps-modules/u-blox-6-timing-module/lea-m8f-precision-timing-gnss-module.html

Electing the nomenclature 'gps' for a GNSS sensor in Gazebo suggests that the sensor is restricted to one satellite system, whereas it may not be.

I'm not too sure how difficult the change would be, and if it is worth all of the hassle it may create. However, it may be good to keep this in mind if an opportunity arises where it can be renamed without too much overhead.

The reason I am being pedantic about this is that I have written a single-frequency multi-constellation GNSS error model, which I'd like to repackage as a sensor plugin. I'm in the process of testing the model on real data, and I will distribute it as a separate project from CRATES when it's in good shape / the paper is written :)

values.title: Inclusion of an altimeter sensor

content.raw:
This will be the last of my issue tracker 'sensor spam' this evening. I'm proposing that we add an altimeter sensor to Gazebo. The sensor will simply report the vertical altitude relative to a reference height ('U' value in the ENU local tangent plane). 

GNSS (GPS, Galileo, GLONASS,etc.) altitude is normally terrible because of satellite geometry. So, multirotor platforms typically make use of barometric pressure sensors to measure altitude. The basic idea is that there is a fairly good relationship between atmospheric pressure and relative height, which you can exploit to estimate altitude. 

The change would be something along these lines in the model SDF:

```
#!xml

<sensor name="BMP180" type="altimeter">
  <pose>0.01 0 0.03 0 -0 0</pose>
  <noise>
    <type>gaussian</type>
    <mean>0.0</mean>
    <stddev>0.01</stddev>
  </noise>
</sensor>

```
content.html:
This will be the last of my issue tracker 'sensor spam' this evening. I'm proposing that we add an altimeter sensor to Gazebo. The sensor will simply report the vertical altitude relative to a reference height ('U' value in the ENU local tangent plane).

GNSS (GPS, Galileo, GLONASS,etc.) altitude is normally terrible because of satellite geometry. So, multirotor platforms typically make use of barometric pressure sensors to measure altitude. The basic idea is that there is a fairly good relationship between atmospheric pressure and relative height, which you can exploit to estimate altitude.

The change would be something along these lines in the model SDF:

<sensor name="BMP180" type="altimeter">
  <pose>0.01 0 0.03 0 -0 0</pose>
  <noise>
    <type>gaussian</type>
    <mean>0.0</mean>
    <stddev>0.01</stddev>
  </noise>
</sensor>

values.title: ArrangePlugin seg-faults if SetArrangement is called after a model is deleted

content.html:
I tried the following to fix it, but it doesn't help:

diff -r 07900b8ef82f plugins/ArrangePlugin.cc
--- a/plugins/ArrangePlugin.cc  Thu Oct 09 11:54:13 2014 -0700
+++ b/plugins/ArrangePlugin.cc  Fri Oct 10 11:17:52 2014 -0700
@@ -149,6 +149,7 @@
 /////////////////////////////////////////////////
 bool ArrangePlugin::SetArrangement(const std::string &_arrangement)
 {
+  bool result = true;
   if (this->arrangements.find(_arrangement) == this->arrangements.end())
   {
     gzerr << "Cannot SetArrangement ["
@@ -179,9 +180,20 @@
       // use initial pose
       pose = iter->second->pose;
     }
-    model->SetWorldPose(pose);
-    model->ResetPhysicsStates();
+    if (model)
+    {
+      model->SetWorldPose(pose);
+      model->ResetPhysicsStates();
+    }
+    else
+    {
+      gzerr << "model ["
+            << iter->first
+            << "] may have been deleted"
+            << std::endl;
+      result = false;
+    }
   }
-  return true;
+  return result;
 }

values.title: INTEGRATION_world_clone failures can leave rogue gzserver processes

content.raw:
The `INTEGRATION_world_clone` test spawns external `gzserver` processes and then tears them down (see [world_clone.cc:199](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/7cf2bfe6c08ac6af0ec4282811d3b6c0355698d4/test/integration/world_clone.cc?at=default#cl-199)). If the test has an internal failure, it might not reach the point where it terminates the external `gzserver` process. This has happened two times recently, and it causes all the other tests to fail:

* http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-coverage-trusty-amd64/73/
* http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/99/

Should we update the [tool/check_test_ran.py](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/default/tools/check_test_ran.py) to kill any external gzserver instances that it sees?
content.html:
The INTEGRATION_world_clone test spawns external gzserver processes and then tears them down (see world_clone.cc:199). If the test has an internal failure, it might not reach the point where it terminates the external gzserver process. This has happened two times recently, and it causes all the other tests to fail:

  • http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-coverage-trusty-amd64/73/
  • http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/99/

Should we update the tool/check_test_ran.py to kill any external gzserver instances that it sees?
